title: Influence of growth temperature on defect density in 1.3 mu m GaInNAs-based lasers
abstract: We show that the dramatic changes in threshold current density with changing active region growth temperature in 1.3mum GaInNAs-based lasers can be attributed nearly entirely to changes in the defect related monomolecular recombination current.

Influence of Growth Temperature on Defect Density in 1.3pm GaInNAs-based lasers 
R. Fehse'*, S.J. Sweeney', A.R. Adams', D. McConville', H. Riecher?, L. Geelhaa? 
'Advanced Technology Institute, University of Surrey, Guildford, GU2 7XH, UK 
Infineon Technologies AG, Corporate Research, D-8 1730 Munich, Germany 
'now at NMRC, Lee Maltings, Prospect Row, Cork, Ireland 
2 
We show that the dramatic changes in threshold current density with changing active region growth 
temperature in 1.3pm GaInNAs-based lasers can be attributed nearly entirely to changes in the defect 
related monomolecular recombination current. 
Lasers based upon GaInNAdGaAs have become of major interest as an alternative to 
InGaAsP/InP. Better electron confinement is expected, because of the much larger conduction band 
offset and because wide-bandgap AlGaAs can be used to form the cladding regions. This both reduces 
carrier leakage and improves optical waveguiding. Most importantly, it also makes possible the 
fabrication of highly reflecting Bragg stacks and hence the production of 1 . 3 ~  wavelength vertical- 
cavity surface-emitting lasers for use in metro-area optical fibre communication. 
In this paper we will describe investigations of the influence of the growth temperature of the 
active region on the magnitude of the main recombination mechanisms at lasing threshold of 1.3pm 
single quantum-well (SQW) GaInNAdGaAs lasers grown by MBE. The laser structures used in this 
study are GaInNAs based SQW devices grown by molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) on n'- GaAs 
substrates. The GaInNAs QWs have an In-content of about 30%, an N-content of about 1.6% and a 
width of 6.5 nm. Two nominally identical series were grown with the only difference being the 
growth temperature of the active region,T,, which was set to be 422°C and 456°C respectively.

Figure 1 Current densities for the three main recombination processes versus temperature. 
In figure 1 the current density (solid line), J&, for an active region growth temperature T, = 422°C (a) 
and T, = 456°C (b) is plotted as a function of device temperature. Around room temperature (T=290K) 
we observe that Jth - 970 A/cmz for the low T, lasers, while Jth - 330 A/cm2 for the higher T, devices. 
To determine which recombination processes are mainly responsible for this nearly factor 3 reduction 
in J& we utilize a method, successfully applied before, which enables the experimental determination 
of the monomolecular-, radiative- and Auger-related current contributions to the threshold current by 
studying the integrated spontaneous emission rate from a window milled into the n-contact of the

increase leading to an increasing temperature sensitivity of Jth. This is reflected in the drop of To 
(closed circles) for temperatures P 1 8 0 K  in figure 2. For the high T, laser, To (open circles) is slightly 
larger for T480K. This is again consistent with the findings from figure lb as the defect related 
contribution is less dominant and the lower temperature sensitivity of the radiative component (To=T 
for an ideal QW) increases the overall To. For T>180K the Auger current in figure lb  increases, 
leading to a drop of TO (open circles) in figure 2. It can be clearly observed that To is decreasing much 
more strongly for the high T, laser (open circles) than for the low T, device (closed circles), leading to 
a cross over point at about 230K. Close to room temperature (280K) we find To(422"C) = 95K and 
To(456"C) = 77K. The lower To of the high T, laser is consistent with the higher relative Auger 
contribution (-45% for 456°C and -30% for 422°C ) to Jth due to lower defect related recombination. 
For Auger dominated threshold currents To < T/3. 
An interesting observation was made when comparing SQW and MQW lasers with nominally 
identical QWs. As expected when decreasing nh, due to the larger modal gain the Auger current (-n3) 
is reduced relatively to the radiative current (-n2) when going from one to three wells However, the 
monomolecular contribution (-n) is reduced by approximately the same amount as the Auger 
component, which cannot be explained by a reduction in nth alone but requires a further decrease in the 
coefficient A. The origin of this surprising effect is subject of ongoing investigations.
